description-en: A multi-coloured map of India and Pakistan, right after the partition of the subcontinent and before the various princely states have been merged into India. Gandhi smiles down at the map from the upper right corner. (gs)
text-en: NEW INDIA No. 688
text-en: ECM [signet]
text-en: R. S. Mukerjee

explanatory comments/crosstagging: West and East Pakistan are green colored; the princely states are yellow; the rest of India is red. The print also shows Afghanistan, Nepal, Burma and Ceylon colored white. Also given are the names of major and minor cities. () (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The absence of a halo around Gandhi's head, as well as the appearance of the various princely states suggests that this map was printed right after August 1947. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The appearance of the name “Rajputana” suggests as well that the map on this print dates to a period between 1947-1948 since after that year the name Rajasthan was adopted to designate this state. (Sumathi Ramaswamy)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The emphasis is certainly on distinguishing Pakistan (in deep green) from the “new” India, but the artist—whose name might well be R. S. Mukherjee, as printed on the bottom right—also appears to be keen on showing the continuing presence of the so-called “princely” states which are set off in bright yellow within Indian national territory—not yet divided up into the fourteen new administrative units—colored red. Gandhi beams down on the newly created nation-state, his haloed presence possibly dating this print to after his death in January 1948, although by the time of his death the vast majority of these princely states had merged into India or Pakistan (some rather contentiously), dissolving their autonomous identities over the course of 1948-49. (Sumathi Ramaswamy)(gs)
